question_text:
A worker in a factory stacks metal sheets on top of each other. The first sheet is 3.3 centimetres thick. Next comes a sheet that is 8.8 centimetres thick, and then a third sheet that is 8.5 centimetres thick. When the worker is done stacking them, how thick will the stack of metal sheets be?


_ centimetres
solution:
Remember to line up the decimal points. Add the decimals and add as you would add whole numbers.
Add: 3.3 + 8.8 + 8.5 = 20.6

Remember to write the decimal point in the answer.
The sum is 20.6.
The stack will be 20.6 centimetres thick.

Remember to line up the decimal points. Add the decimals and add as you would add whole numbers.
Add: 5.9 + 2.3 + 8.5 = 16.7

Remember to write the decimal point in the answer.
The sum is 16.7.
The stack will be 16.7 millimetres thick.

question_text:
A carpenter in a workshop stacks wooden boards on top of each other. The first sheet is 6.2 centimetres thick. Next comes a sheet that is 6.1 centimetres thick, and then a third sheet that is 2.2 centimetres thick. When the carpenter is done stacking them, how thick will the stack of wooden boards be?


_ centimetres
solution:
Remember to line up the decimal points. Add the decimals and add as you would add whole numbers.
Add: 6.2 + 6.1 + 2.2 = 14.5

Remember to write the decimal point in the answer.
The sum is 14.5.
The stack will be 14.5 centimetres thick.

question_text:
A florist in a flower shop stacks foam blocks on top of each other. The first sheet is 8.5 centimetres thick. Next comes a sheet that is 9.1 centimetres thick, and then a third sheet that is 7.6 centimetres thick. When the florist is done stacking them, how thick will the stack of foam blocks be?


_ centimetres
solution:
Remember to line up the decimal points. Add the decimals and add as you would add whole numbers.
Add: 8.5 + 9.1 + 7.6 = 25.2

Remember to write the decimal point in the answer.
The sum is 25.2.
The stack will be 25.2 centimetres thick.

question_text:
A Bruce Wayne in a Batcave stacks kevlar sheets on top of each other. The first sheet is 3.8 centimetres thick. Next comes a sheet that is 4.6 centimetres thick, and then a third sheet that is 1.3 centimetres thick. When the Bruce Wayne is done stacking them, how thick will the stack of kevlar sheets be?


_ centimetres
solution:
Remember to line up the decimal points. Add the decimals and add as you would add whole numbers.
Add: 3.8 + 4.6 + 1.3 = 9.7

Remember to write the decimal point in the answer.
The sum is 9.7.
The stack will be 9.7 centimetres thick.
